finding: This SNP was associated with omega-3% in males, serving as an X-chromosomal locus identified in male-only GWAS. It was linked to the gene ACOT9, which regulates fatty and amino acid metabolism in mitochondria.
title: Genome-wide association studies and multi-omics integrative analysis reveal novel loci and their molecular mechanisms for circulating polyunsaturated, monounsaturated, and saturated fatty acids

finding: For SNP rs1044165 in the MIR223 gene, only the heterozygous model revealed significant association with CHD, having an odds ratio of 0.3442 (0.1308-0.9055; P = 0.0276). Other genetic models did not show significant relationships.
title: The potential impact of microRNA-related functional polymorphisms in the pathogenesis of coronary heart disease

finding: This SNP was noted as significant from COJO analyses, located on the X chromosome, which may contribute to sex differences in C3 and C4 concentrations as well as the risk of autoimmune disorders.
title: The genetic and phenotypic correlates of neonatal Complement Component 3 and 4 protein concentrations with a focus on psychiatric and autoimmune disorders

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with impulsivity near the POLA1 gene, which has been linked to neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: The association with varicose veins was identified in connection to this variant.
title: Insights from complex trait fine-mapping across diverse populations

finding: A non-synonymous SNV (A/T) was identified in C1GALT1C1 at position 120,626,774 on the X chromosome, resulting in the amino acid change to D131E, which was associated with polyagglutinable erythrocyte syndrome.
title: A newly identified pathology of Episodic Angioedema with Hypereosinophilia (Gleich’s Syndrome) revealed by Multi-Omics Analysis

finding: SNP rs4830976 was associated with COVID-19 hospitalization through strong correlations with ACE2, exhibiting a positive MR association with a beta-coefficient of 0.34 (95% CI: 0.17-0.51; P=8.1×10<sup>-5</sup>). It was identified as a key eQTL influencing ACE2 levels.
title: Actionable druggable genome-wide Mendelian randomization identifies repurposing opportunities for COVID-19

finding: The rs140104197 variant, a protein-truncating variant (PTV) in MAP3K15, was significantly associated with a reduced risk of both type 1 diabetes (T1DM) and type 2 diabetes (T2DM) in the FinnGen study, with odds ratios (OR) of 0.58 (P=4.9x10^-4) for T1DM and 0.82 (P=0.04) for T2DM. This variant had a higher minor allele frequency (MAF) in Finnish individuals compared to UKB Europeans.
title: Human genetic evidence supports MAP3K15 inhibition as a therapeutic strategy for diabetes

finding: This testosterone variant on chromosome X was associated with increased testosterone levels across all ancestry groups and was significantly linked with lower odds of diabetes specifically in the African ancestry group.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This African-specific variant on chromosome X was uniquely associated with diabetes, diabetic retinopathy, and renal failure. It indicated a connection between lower testosterone levels and chronic kidney issues in the African ancestry group.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: This variant showed a unique association with hereditary hemolytic anemias in the Hispanic ancestry group, indicating its potential role in anemia regulation.
title: Discovery of Novel Trans-Ancestry and Ancestry-Specific Gene Loci for Total Testosterone in a Multi-Ancestral Analysis of Men in the Million Veteran Program

finding: The SNP rs9697983 was identified through pathway analysis as a candidate causal SNP located in the gene GLUD2, which was associated with electronic transport and metabolism pathways relevant to age-related macular degeneration (AMD). This finding highlighted the significance of pathways involving the nervous system and blood coagulation, both of which were previously recognized as important in AMD.
title: Identifying X-Chromosome Variants Associated with Age-Related Macular Degeneration

finding: The rs6610096 SNP was identified as significant in male, female, and combined analyses, specifically located in the PAGE4 gene. This gene is implicated in several cancers and had inverse correlations with cancer progression. The findings suggest that this SNP may play a role in TB susceptibility potentially through its involvement in immune function.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The rs7888114 SNP reached significance in male, female, and combined analyses, located in the FRMPD4 gene. Although the function of FRMPD4 regarding TB susceptibility was unclear, it was identified previously in SNP interaction analyses, indicating a potential role in immune response.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: This SNP was identified as significant in the Ghanaian female analysis and combined analyses, located downstream of the ACTRT1 gene. Its identification suggested potential involvement in TB susceptibility, especially considering CX chromosome dynamics in females where it may escape inactivation leading to its overexpression.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: Identified in the male Asian cohorts, this SNP was associated with TB susceptibility within the LINC01546 gene locus, although its exact function and influence on susceptibility remain unclear due to a lack of available functional information.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: Found to be significant in the male Asian cohorts, similar to rs1726176, it was associated with the LINC01546 gene and may have implications for TB susceptibility, but functional details were not clear.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: This SNP was also significant in male Asian cohorts as part of the LINC01546 region, reflecting a potential association with TB susceptibility although, as with the others, functional implications were not well defined.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: This SNP was significant in the female African cohort and associated with the UPF3B gene. This gene regulates nonsense mediated decay and might influence TB susceptibility through its role in RNA regulation linked to immune defense.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: This SNP was significant in male cohorts, located in the non-coding RNA LOC105373293. Its function is unknown, but its association adds to the growing data on TB susceptibility gene variants.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: Associated with the BRS3 gene, this SNP was significant in the combined analysis, linking it to energy metabolism that might have implications for TB susceptibility.
title: X-linked multi-ancestry meta-analysis reveals tuberculosis susceptibility variants

finding: The SNP rs12687599 was associated with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), located in a significant region on chrXp22.2, linked to the genes ASB9 and ASB11. The p-value was notably low at 3.57×10⁻⁷, indicating robust evidence for its association.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs5926125 was identified as a lead SNP associated with ASD, encompassing the long non-coding RNA DDX53/PTCHD1-AS. This SNP had a p-value of 9.47×10⁻⁶, confirming its relevance in ASD pathogenesis.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: The SNP rs767542284 was determined to be significant in the Both-XWAS, located in the PDHA1 gene. This variant had significant p-values in all subset analyses.
title: Chromosome X-Wide Common Variant Association Study (XWAS) in Autism Spectrum Disorder

finding: This SNP was recognized for its relevance in PSA level associations, further contributing to genetic predisposition understanding in prostate cancer.
title: Incorporating Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Improves Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: Identified as TEX11, rs62608084 was significantly associated with PSA levels and contributed to novel genetic findings.
title: Incorporating Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Improves Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The SNP rs4829762 was linked with GPC3 and played a significant role in the association with PSA levels.
title: Incorporating Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Improves Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: Located in EDA, rs2520386 was identified as significantly associated with PSA levels, aiding in understanding genetic predispositions.
title: Incorporating Genetic Determinants of Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels Improves Prostate Cancer Screening

finding: The rs3810682 SNP, identified as a g.50910775C>G polymorphism in the promoter region of the BMP15 gene, was observed in 3 cases with a prevalence of 10.7% among POF patients, compared to a prevalence of 3.3% in controls. Among the cases, one was homozygous for the SNP while two were heterozygous. Although the findings demonstrated a higher prevalence in the cases, the p-value of 0.344 indicated no significant difference at a 95% significance level. The presence of this SNP was associated with cases of both primary and secondary amenorrhea, suggesting its role in the manifestation of premature ovarian failure.
title: Cytogenetic & Molecular analysis in Premature Ovarian Failure

finding: The SNP rs12010150 was associated with significantly elevated polygenic risk scores (PRS) for type 1 diabetes (T1D), hypothyroidism, and psoriasis in exceptional responders (ERs) to cancer treatment. This indicated a potential link between these autoimmune-related diseases and cancer treatment efficacy, contrasting with typical cancer patients.
title: Polygenic risk scores for autoimmune related diseases are significantly different and skewed in cancer exceptional responders

finding: The variant rs1190734 exhibited a genome-wide significant association with 'heavy-smoker' in admixture-specific GWAS (OR=0.83; P=1.2e-11), reflecting its influence on smoking behavior in various ancestries.
title: Rare coding variants in CHRNB2 reduce the likelihood of smoking

finding: The SNP rs1050828, a missense variant in G6PD, had significant associations with multiple phenotypes such as glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) and red blood cell-related traits in the African ancestry group. It presented a p-value of 1.1 x 10<sup>-299</sup> for HbA1c with a substantial within-group frequency of 16% compared to 1.5 x 10<sup>-4</sup> in EUR populations, reaffirming its pleiotropic effects.
title: Pan-UK Biobank GWAS improves discovery, analysis of genetic architecture, and resolution into ancestry-enriched effects

finding: The study found that the polymorphism at rs3810682: g.50910775C>G in the promoter region of the BMP15 gene was present in 10.7% of cases with Premature Ovarian Failure (POF) compared to 3.3% in healthy controls. Although the prevalence was higher in POF cases, the p-value of 0.344 indicated that the finding was not statistically significant at the 95% confidence level. The study suggested that this SNP may be linked to altered gene expression, contributing to both primary and secondary amenorrhea in affected individuals.
title: Cytogenetic & Molecular analysis in Premature Ovarian Failure

finding: This lead variant showed a strong association with AF, having an odds ratio of 2.00, indicating a significant contribution to the development of AF via its location in an intron of the FGF13 gene, which is implicated in cardiac conduction.
title: Trans-ancestry genome-wide analysis of atrial fibrillation provides new insights into disease biology and enables polygenic prediction of cardioembolic risk

finding: The SNP rs12010166 was discussed in the context of its relevance to combination therapies in cancer treatment, emphasizing that multidrug cancer therapies could provide better financial value than traditional monotherapies. The study highlighted effective molecular targeting in treatment decisions, which could be informed by such genetic markers.
title: Gaining Control of Combination Cancer Treatment Risk by Incorporating Cost and Value Data into the Drug Selection Process at the Point–of–Care

finding: The variant rs184476359 in the AR gene was found to be genome-wide significant in the multi-ancestry discovery phase (p = 3.4e-10) and had a replication p-value of 6.3e-4, with a MAF of 17.7% in African ancestry individuals.
title: Genome-wide association study of prostate-specific antigen levels in 392,522 men identifies new loci and improves cross-ancestry prediction

finding: The SNP rs35318931 (p.Ser413Phe) located in the SRPX gene was also fine-mapped with high confidence (87.3% probability) as a causal variant. The SRPX gene is implicated in extracellular matrix function and its variant might influence ECM's structural properties, highlighting a potential role in HEM pathophysiology.
title: Genome-wide analysis of 944,133 individuals provides insights into the etiology of hemorrhoidal disease

finding: The variant rs913664484 was identified in the STAG2 gene, a gene associated with severe congenital and developmental defects as well as cancers. This T>G transversion was found to disrupt a splicing site, indicating a high impact on the gene product. This variant was noted in a male embryo, emphasizing its potential role in the embryo's development and its relation to miscarriage.
title: Prioritization of putatively detrimental variants in euploid miscarriages

finding: The SNP rs1050828 in the G6PD gene was significantly associated with multiple phenotypes (e.g., glycated hemoglobin, p = 1.1 x 10^-299) in the African ancestry cohort where its allele frequency was 16%. In the European group, this SNP had a frequency of only 1.5 x 10^-4%, indicating its potential influence in diverse ancestry contexts.
title: Pan-UK Biobank GWAS improves discovery, analysis of genetic architecture, and resolution into ancestry-enriched effects

finding: The rs12400785 SNP located near the CHRDL1 gene on the X chromosome was associated with neonatal jaundice (OR = 0.80; p-value = 3.4 × 10^-11), indicating a link to reduced risk for jaundice.
title: Genome-wide analysis of neonatal jaundice reveals a marked departure from adult bilirubin metabolism

finding: The lead SNP rs5942980 on the X chromosome was strongly linked to the lead SNP for neonatal jaundice at the same locus, showing consistent effects driven by transmitted alleles.
title: Genome-wide analysis of neonatal jaundice reveals a marked departure from adult bilirubin metabolism

finding: This SNP was associated with a variety of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) measures, indicating its relevance in brain structure assessments.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: This SNP was linked to brain volume (BV), cortical areas, and brain shape, reflecting its impact on brain morphology.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: This SNP was associated with the volume of the right ventral diencephalon (hypothalamus) and linked to several neuropsychiatric disorders, including schizophrenia, suggesting a strong genetic correlation with brain anatomy and function.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: Associated with educational attainment, this SNP was also linked to the volume of the right ventral diencephalon, highlighting its role in cognitive functions.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: This SNP served as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for FAM3A, affecting gene expression in brain tissues and linked to schizophrenia, underscoring its significance in neuropsychiatric contexts.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: Identified differences in left rostral middle frontal cortex thickness (CT) between sexes, illustrating its role in sex-specific brain structure variations.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: This SNP had divergent effects on the radial diffusivity (RD) of the anterior corona radiata between sexes, indicating its importance in understanding sex differences in brain imaging traits.
title: The pivotal role of the X-chromosome in the genetic architecture of the human brain

finding: The alternative allele in homozygosis for rs228406, mapping to the gene DMD, was associated with the noFAST phenotype. Patients with this variant exhibited a higher proportion of subjects harboring the reference allele in homozygosis when compared to the FAST group, indicating a potential protective effect against rapid renal progression.
title: IDENTIFICATION OF MODIFIER GENE VARIANTS OVERREPRESENTED IN FAMILIAL HYPOMAGNESEMIA WITH HYPERCALCIURIA AND NEPHROCALCINOSIS PATIENTS WITH A MORE AGGRESSIVE RENAL PHENOTYPE

finding: The SNP rs1050828, which is a variant in the <italic>G6PD</italic> gene, was found to significantly shorten the mean erythrocyte lifespan, leading to a misdiagnosis of approximately 0.65 million African-American individuals with Type 2 Diabetes (T2D). This variant altered the relationship between measured HbA1C and true blood glucose levels, thereby affecting T2D diagnosis. The presence of this SNP in about 11% of African-Americans highlights its role in misdiagnosis due to its impact on hematologic properties.
title: A combined polygenic score of 21,293 rare and 22 common variants significantly improves diabetes diagnosis based on hemoglobin A1C levels

finding: The SNP rs6612886 was notably significant in allelic shift analyses, indicating a preferential retention of alleles likely involved in the selection process during mLOX development.
title: Population analyses of mosaic X chromosome loss identify genetic drivers and widespread signatures of cellular selection

finding: This variant in EFNB1 was linked to various ophthalmologic abnormalities and was shown to affect retinal thickness significantly, grounding it within the context of craniofrontonasal syndrome.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: An intronic variant in SHROOM2, it was significantly associated with retinal thickness, further connecting it with pigmentation of the retinal pigment epithelium.
title: Multi-omic spatial effects on high-resolution AI-derived retinal thickness

finding: An association with impulsivity was identified (p=1.50E-8) in the POLA1 gene on the X chromosome, which is newly related to impulsivity despite earlier links to blood traits and neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: CADM2 is implicated in impulsive personality and numerous other traits by genome- and phenome-wide association studies in humans and mice

finding: The SNP rs17332232 was identified as being associated with the risk of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) through X chromosome analysis. Specifically, this SNP was linked to the gene IL1RAPL2, which encodes a central nervous system-specific protein and plays a role in the interactome of interleukin-2. This cytokine is currently under investigation for its potential neuroprotective effects in ALS, suggesting that the stratification of clinical trial results by this SNP's genotype could reveal a pharmacogenomic element influencing therapeutic outcomes in ALS.
title: Sex-specific risk loci and modified MEF2C expression in ALS

finding: The SNP rs145400922 was associated with cardioembolic stroke at the genome-wide significance level in an analysis restricted to Black participants, highlighting its relevance in a specific demographic.
title: Whole Exome Sequencing Analyses Support a Role of Vitamin D Metabolism in Ischemic Stroke

finding: This was identified as a deleterious non-synonymous variant (Lys341Arg) prevalent in Central African hunter-gatherers (CAHG) with a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 0.164. It was associated with extended haplotype homozygosity suggesting positive selection in this population.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: This variant (Leu731Phe) also had high MAF (0.083) in the CAHG population. Its presence contributes to the evidence of positive selection alongside another common variant (rs145437639).
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: The variant (Asp597Glu) shared high MAF (0.083) in the CAHG population indicating positive selection in this ethnic group. Together with rs138390800 and rs147311723, they were the only common coding variants found at ACE2.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: An eQTL variant, it was associated with various clinical phenotypes, including respiratory disorders within African American populations.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: Another eQTL variant significantly associated with type 2 diabetes (p=1.23 x 10^-4, OR=1.1), particularly in African American populations.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: This eQTL variant showed significance in association with hypertension (p=8.8 x 10^-4, OR=1.13) in the African American population.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: Identified as a regulatory variant in the CAHG population (MAF = 0.153), it showed extreme differentiation from other populations.
title: Global patterns of genetic variation and association with clinical phenotypes at genes involved in SARS-CoV-2 infection

finding: The variant rs525496 was identified in an X-chromosome wide association study (XWAS) for Parkinson disease (PD) risk, demonstrating an odds ratio (OR) of 0.60 in the discovery cohort with a significant p-value (p = 3.13 × 10^-5). It was further replicated in males with the same OR of 0.60 and a p-value of 0.04. This variant acted as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for several genes associated with brain tissues, including RAB9B, H2BFM, TSMB15B, and GLRA4.
title: X-Chromosome Association Study in Latin American Cohorts Identifies New Loci in Parkinson Disease

finding: The variant rs28602900 was replicated from previous studies, showing a positive association with Parkinson disease across both genders, with an odds ratio greater than 1. This finding reinforced the understanding of the role of the X chromosome in PD as it was replicated in a new cohort that included both males and females.
title: X-Chromosome Association Study in Latin American Cohorts Identifies New Loci in Parkinson Disease

finding: The splice donor pLoF variant, rs5987128, was associated with reduced blood pressure (BP). This finding was deemed novel as it is located on the X-chromosome and was previously excluded from large GWAS efforts. The variant had a minor allele frequency (MAF) of 12%.
title: Association analyses of predicted loss-of-function variants prioritized 15 genes as blood pressure regulators

finding: The SNP rs16997659 was noted as a lead trans-eQTL variant for EIF2S3B, contributing significantly to its expression (R² > 0.8).
title: Whole Genome DNA and RNA Sequencing of Whole Blood Elucidates the Genetic Architecture of Gene Expression Underlying a Wide Range of Diseases

finding: The Arg1122* PTV (rs140104197) was significantly associated with a reduced risk of both type 1 diabetes (T1DM) and type 2 diabetes (T2DM) in FinnGen study, with an odds ratio (OR) of 0.58 (P = 4.9×10^-4) for T1DM and OR of 0.82 (P = 0.04) for T2DM.
title: Human genetic evidence supports MAP3K15 inhibition as a therapeutic strategy for diabetes

finding: The rs76723693 G6PD variant was linked to lower RDW, particularly within African populations, showcasing a commonality in hemolytic phenomenon.
title: Whole genome sequencing association analysis of quantitative red blood cell phenotypes: the NHLBI TOPMed program

finding: The common variant rs6048, a missense variant in F9 (F9 Malmö), was replicated in the study, confirming its association with VTE.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: An upstream variant rs3002417 of BCOR was identified, which indicated its potential relevance in the etiology of thrombotic conditions.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The intronic variant rs17328181 in FUNDC2 showed a prior nominal association with VTE, situating it in a context related to platelet survival.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS for venous thromboembolism identifies novel loci followed by experimental validation in zebrafish

finding: The analysis demonstrated that the rare variant rs190509934, located 60 base pairs upstream of the ACE2 gene on the X chromosome, was associated with a 39% reduction in ACE2 expression in carriers compared to non-carriers. This reduction in expression correlated with a decreased risk of COVID-19 infection (OR=0.60, P=4.5x10^-13) and a suggestion of reduced severity of disease among infected individuals.
title: Genome-wide analysis in 756,646 individuals provides first genetic evidence that ACE2 expression influences COVID-19 risk and yields genetic risk scores predictive of severe disease

finding: The SNP chrX:154535277:T:C was identified as part of the variants found in the G6PD gene among individuals with a diagnosis of G6PD deficiency. This specific variant was noted for being the minor allele in the group of 82 individuals diagnosed with G6PD deficiency. Its inclusion in the genetic testing panels provides context for understanding the variability of deficiency-causing variants among different individuals, thereby emphasizing the importance of comprehensive genetic testing for G6PD. This finding supports improved interpretation and management of G6PD deficiency.
title: Functional Analysis of G6PD Variants Associated With Low G6PD Activity in the All of Us Research Program

finding: The rs4549940 variant was found to be associated with uric acid levels, replicating previous findings in the UK Biobank.
title: Understanding Complex Trait Susceptibilities and Ethnical Diversity in a Sample of 4,145 Russians Through Analysis of Clinical and Genetic Data

finding: The rs1059702 variant, associated with IRAK1, was identified as one of the allelic variants that could alter the amino acid sequence of proteins. This variant was included among the 51 variants exhibiting enhancer activity related to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The rs3027878 variant was associated with HCFC1 and was characterized as having dual-use codons which could also alter the protein sequence, suggesting a role as an allelic enVar in SLE risk loci.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The variant rs4830974 in the ACE2 gene showed a weak association with lower basophil percentages and a weak protective effect for hypertension. This was notable because the ACE2 gene is known for its role in blood pressure regulation.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The low-frequency intronic variant rs183546232 in the ACE2 gene was nominally associated with eosinophilic esophagitis in an independent dataset, indicating a potential predisposition to gastro-oesophageal reflux disease with oesophagitis.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The variant chrX:15600835:T:C, known as p.K26R, changed an amino acid adjacent to a SARS-CoV-2 interacting site but was not predicted to be damaging. This variant had an allele frequency of approximately 0.5% in multiple populations.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The chrX:15600857:A:G variant, resulting in p.S19P, was a damaging variant that directly affected the SARS-CoV-2 interacting amino acid. It was very rare or absent in most populations but had an allele frequency of 0.1-0.2% in populations with African ancestry.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The SNP rs62621675, with a genotype change of [C>G], was analyzed using AsCRISPR and resulted in the identification of 24 discriminating sgRNAs. This SNP created novel PAM sequences that allowed for enhanced CRISPR targeting of the variant allele.
title: AsCRISPR: a web server for allele-specific sgRNA design in precision medicine

finding: This SNP was identified as the top SNP in a cluster associated with 96 imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs) related to white matter tracts throughout the cerebrum. It was located about 10 kb from FAM58A, an eQTL whose mutations are linked to STAR, leading to notable brain variations such as incomplete hippocampal inversion.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was part of a cluster associated with various nIDPs, including disease diagnoses. It had been previously seen in a GWAS of Type 2 diabetes and is located in an intron of DUSP9, a gene that protects against stress-induced insulin resistance.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was the top SNP in a cluster associated with local brain volume across the occipital lobe. It is located in a pseudoautosomal region and serves as an eQTL affecting genes linked to developmental disorders, including RAB39B.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was the leading SNP in a cluster associated with gray matter volume in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. It is positioned near ZIC3, a gene linked to body pattern formation and left-right asymmetry, with implications in neural tube development and brain structural abnormalities.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: This SNP was significantly associated with 50 phenotypes in the PheWAS catalog and specifically linked to cystic fibrosis severity with a GWAS p-value of 2e-6.
title: Cell type-specific expression of angiotensin receptors in the human lung with implications for health, aging, and chronic disease

finding: This SNP was identified as the only non-autosomal variant and was previously linked to traits such as age of first sexual intercourse and educational attainment.
title: Polygenic predictions of occupational status GWAS elucidate genetic and environmental interplay for intergenerational status transmission, careers, and health

finding: The SNP rs7886851 in the MAGED1 gene was significantly associated with the transition from first cocaine use to cocaine use disorder (CUD), as indicated by the log-rank test yielding a p value of 0.002. This suggested a vital role of MAGED1 variants in influencing cocaine addiction pathways.
title: USP7/Maged1-Mediated H2A Monoubiquitination in the Paraventricular Thalamus: An Epigenetic Mechanism Involved in Cocaine Use Disorder

finding: Similar to rs7886851, SNP rs6614508 in the MAGED1 gene also showed a significant association with the transition from first cocaine use to CUD, with a log-rank test yielding a p value of 0.002, highlighting its importance in the genetic predisposition to cocaine addiction.
title: USP7/Maged1-Mediated H2A Monoubiquitination in the Paraventricular Thalamus: An Epigenetic Mechanism Involved in Cocaine Use Disorder

finding: The SNP rs6641874 was found to associate significantly with lymphocyte counts, with larger effect sizes observed in females compared to males in multiple analyses including BBJ and UKB datasets. This suggested that the expression of the PRKX gene, which is located in proximity to this SNP, could play a role in influencing lymphocyte counts in females due to the differential escape from X chromosome inactivation.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The SNP rs6641601 was identified as the top variant in monocyte eQTL analyses, indicating its involvement in gene expression regulation. Similar to rs6641874, it contributed to the understanding of how variations in the PRKX gene locus could be associated with immune cell composition, particularly in monocytes, thus reflecting the nuances of sex differences in gene regulation through X chromosome inactivation.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The association between pyruvate levels in RBCs and rs142516556, close to the G6PD gene, remained robust across various analyses, confirming its role in metabolic regulation.
title: Genome-wide metabolite quantitative trait loci analysis (mQTL) in red blood cells from volunteer blood donors

finding: The SNP rs387906727 in the RPL10 gene was identified as deleterious in relation to Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). This finding indicated a potential impact on the synaptic compartment, contributing to the pathogenesis of ASD.
title: In silico analysis of the altered protein structure and functions caused by existing synaptic gene mutations in Indian population having neurological disorders

finding: The SNP rs3827440 was identified as a nonsynonymous single nucleotide polymorphism within the GPR174 gene located on the X chromosome. This finding was associated with Graves' disease in the Polish Caucasian population, contributing to the understanding of the genetic factors influencing this autoimmune condition.
title: Identification of ABHD6 as a regulator of lysophosphatidylserines in the mammalian liver and kidneys

finding: The Asn-Asp missense variant rs1050829 in the G6PD gene was associated with G6PD deficiency. It showed a high value of 68.8, placing it in the top 0.5% of all variants, both on the X chromosome and genome-wide. This variant was highlighted as part of the adaptive evolutionary patterns tied to malaria resistance.
title: Three hallmarks of malaria-induced selection in human genomes

finding: The Ala-Val missense variant rs1340989, located within the ABCB7 gene, was identified as part of a significant signal extending through a 3 Mb region on the X chromosome. This variant was noted for its connection to high observed values in selection scans, contributing to the understanding of genetic diversity influenced by malaria.
title: Three hallmarks of malaria-induced selection in human genomes

finding: The SNP rs6318, also known as Cys23Ser or 68G>C, was found to be associated with several neuropsychiatric diseases including eating and anxiety disorders, obesity, depression, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, and cocaine use disorder. This finding related to the 5-HT2CR gene suggests its significant role in various behavioral and psychiatric conditions.
title: Protein Co-Evolution Strategies Detect Predicted Functional Interaction Between the Serotonin 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C Receptors

finding: The SNP rs12010173 was investigated in the context of understanding tree-to-tree variations in cone production of Stone Pine (Pinus pinea L.), and it was found to correlate with variations in resource allocation strategies among individual trees. The finding detailed how this SNP could affect traits related to growth and reproduction in this plant species.
title: An integrative trait-based framework to infer resource budgets and life-histories of long-lived plants

finding: The analysis of SNP rs11091341 related to breast cancer liver metastases revealed that it was associated with a significant therapeutic response to the fixed-dose small-molecule drug MBC-005. This candidate drug was shown to mediate anti-tumorigenic effects through a p21-dependent mechanism involving the stimulation of the opioid growth factor receptor. Importantly, MBC-005 demonstrated a 3.9-fold increase in survival and a 4-fold decrease in tumor volume in a BALB/c mouse model, indicating the critical role this SNP played in the treatment and prognosis of liver metastases in breast cancer.
title: Reshaping the Landscape of Locoregional Treatments for Breast Cancer Liver Metastases: A novel, intratumoral, p21-targeted percutaneous therapy increases survival in BALB/c mice inoculated with 4T1 triple negative breast cancer cells in the liver

finding: This SNP was linked to IL1RAPL1, associated with intellectual disability and autism, exhibiting a z-score of 5.77.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This SNP was downstream of GAGE1 and showed a z-score of 5.80, connected to glioblastoma-related pathways.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This variant had a z-score of 6.61 and was associated with the phosphatase MTMR8, related to cytoskeleton function.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: The study found that carriage of the ACE2 rs2074192 TT genotype significantly increased ACE2 mRNA and protein expression levels in placental organoids. However, despite the higher expression, ACE2 enzyme activity was notably decreased in TT organoids. Furthermore, the TT organoids exhibited reduced diameters and asymmetrical growth patterns. This SNP was associated with an increased risk of small-for-gestational-age (SGA) newborns, highlighting the importance of the ACE2:ACE ratio in placental development.
title: Genetically edited human placental organoids cast new light on the role of ACE2 in placental development

finding: The pathogenic mutation D168N was found in the myelin proteolipid protein (P60201-2) as part of the variant peptide TSASIGSLCANAR, with 5 confident PSMs. This was an established significant mutation.
title: Quality control of variant peptides identified through proteogenomics- catching the (un)usual suspects

finding: The noncoding variant rs4646118 was found in approximately 9% of individuals of African descent. It was suggested that this variant could influence transcriptional regulation of the ACE2 gene, potentially contributing to increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 among African Americans.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: Similar to rs4646118, the noncoding variant rs143185769 was present in about 9% of African descent individuals. This variant was also proposed to play a role in regulating the expression of the ACE2 gene, further implicating it in the heightened vulnerability of certain populations to SARS-CoV-2.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: The variant rs142984500 (H378R) was noted as being present in only 0.019% of European non-Finnish individuals. It was highlighted for its significance in zinc binding and enzymatic function, with hemizygous occurrences observed in six males, marking it as an important ultra-rare missense variant in the context of ACE2's role in SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: SARS-CoV2 (COVID-19) Structural/Evolution Dynamicome: Insights into functional evolution and human genomics

finding: The SNP rs5935988 was associated with the COBLL1 and GRB14 genes, both of which are relevant to body fat distribution and insulin signaling, highlighting its role in obesity.
title: Identifying latent genetic interactions in genome-wide association studies using multiple traits

finding: For rs185941206, HWE was rejected because females were monomorphic while males carried all three alleles, highlighting a significant difference in allele frequency distribution between sexes.
title: A network algorithm for the X chromosomal exact test for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium with multiple alleles

finding: For rs112679846, males were monomorphic, but females had a large number of alternate alleles, leading to a rejection of HWE; this finding illustrates the importance of including both sexes in genetic analysis.
title: A network algorithm for the X chromosomal exact test for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium with multiple alleles

finding: The SNP rs73635825, resulting in the S19P amino acid variant, was the most frequent among the ACE2 variants studied (0.06% frequency) and showed significant relevance in Spike protein interaction with a GBPM score of -47.6175. This SNP was highlighted as the most impactful variant on binding across four structural models.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs143936283, which causes the E329G amino acid change, was classified as a very rare allele (0.0066%) within the European (non-Finnish) Asian population. It was studied due to its presence in the binding interface, suggesting potential implications for binding affinity with the SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs766996587, causing the M82I amino acid substitution, was also recognized as a very rare variant (0.0066%) found predominantly in the African population. Its potential effects on the binding interaction with the Spike protein were considered, particularly in the context of predicted alterations in affinity.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs146676783 resulted in the E37K mutation, which was observed with a frequency of 0.03% primarily in the Finnish population. It was noted for its placement in the binding interface and was studied for its possible impact on Spike interaction but was categorized as rare.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs370610075, resulting in the G352V variant, had a frequency of 0.007% within the European non-Finnish population. It was identified as a rare variant located in the binding region of ACE2, with implications for its interaction with the SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP (rs28933690) caused a C294R mutation and was confirmed as pathogenic, aligning with clinical findings from the dbSNPs/NCBI database.
title: Unmasking of novel mutations within XK gene that could be used as Diagnostic Markers to Predict McLeod syndrome: Using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP (rs145996031) resulted in a Y370D mutation, which was found to be damaging and potentially associated with L1 syndrome, although it was originally categorized as untested.
title: Unmasking of novel mutations within XK gene that could be used as Diagnostic Markers to Predict McLeod syndrome: Using in silico analysis

finding: The SNP rs1465108 was associated with significant functional connectivity (FC) between the precuneus cluster and the right middle temporal gyrus in adults with ADHD, as evidenced by a correlation of r=-0.22 (P=0.030). This finding was an original positive result linked to neurobiology in ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs5906883 demonstrated a significant correlation with FC between the precuneus cluster and the right middle temporal gyrus in adults with ADHD, with a correlation of r=-0.21 (P=0.037). This finding was noted as an original positive contribution to understanding ADHD genetic influences.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs6323 was significantly associated with FC in the female cohort, with a correlation of r=0.37 (P=0.036) between the precuneus cluster and the precuneus, indicating its role in ADHD-related functional connectivity. This represented an original positive finding.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs5905859 showed significant correlation (r=0.23, P=0.023) with FC between the precuneus and right middle temporal gyrus in the male cohort, marking it as an original positive finding concerning ADHD's genetic basis.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs1799836 was correlated with the FC between left middle temporal cluster and right inferior temporal gyrus at r=0.28 (P=0.005), highlighting its role in ADHD connectivity patterns. This was categorized as an original positive finding.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: For the SNP rs10521432, there was a significant correlation of r=0.36 (P=0.041) between left middle temporal cluster and right superior parietal gyrus in the female group, presenting an original positive finding regarding ADHD functional architecture.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs2239449 was associated with several significant correlations, including with the FC between the precuneus cluster and left calcarine (male r=-0.27, P=0.007; female r=0.39, P=0.025) and the right middle temporal gyrus (male r=-0.22, P=0.027), indicating its crucial role as an original positive finding for ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs2283729 showed significant correlation with various connection patterns, including the left middle temporal cluster to right superior parietal gyrus (female r=-0.37, P=0.035), marking it as an original positive finding in the context of ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs6651806 indicated a significant negative correlation (r=-0.26, P=0.009) between FC in the precuneus to left calcarine in males, denoting its relevance for neurobiological underpinnings of ADHD as an original positive finding.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs2283727 was associated with significant connectivity patterns, particularly between the precuneus and left calcarine (male r=0.20, P=0.041), demonstrating its clinical significance in ADHD and classifying it as an original positive finding.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs3027441 correlated significantly with the FC between left middle temporal cluster and the left superior frontal gyrus at r=0.20 (P=0.045) in males, establishing its relevance as an original positive finding in ADHD.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The SNP rs5952671 showed significant correlation with FC patterns in males (r=-0.22, P=0.027). This finding was categorized as original and positive, helping to elucidate genetic factors affecting ADHD's neural circuitry.
title: Connectome-wide association analysis identified significant brain functional alteration in adults with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder

finding: The TIMP-1 rs6609533 variant was linked to type 2 diabetes susceptibility, highlighting genetic factors in diabetes development.
title: Screening key genes and signaling pathways in COVID-19 infection and its associated complications by integrated bioinformatics analysis

finding: Pasini et al. (2020) provided insights into the functional role of extracellular vesicles in NSCLC, suggesting that variations like rs12010040 could influence resistance to targeted treatment and immunotherapy. The finding indicated that this SNP was relevant to the mechanisms governing treatment efficacy in lung cancer patients.
title: Multiplexed electrokinetic sensor for detection and therapy monitoring of extracellular vesicles from liquid biopsies of non-small-cell lung cancer patients

finding: The analysis of the SNP rs62621675:[C>G] utilized AsCRISPR, which successfully generated 13 discriminating sgRNAs when combined with various subtypes of Cas9, including SpCas9-V(R)QR, SpCas9-EQR, SpCas9-VRER, and CjCas9. Notably, three of the sgRNAs employed novel PAMs created by the SNP, while five additional pairs of sgRNAs featured the variant point within their seed sequences. This exemplified the tool's ability to process heterozygous SNPs effectively for potential allele-specific gene therapy.
title: AsCRISPR: a web server for allele-specific sgRNA design in precision medicine

finding: The SNP rs12010065 was linked to the demographic changes in sympatric populations of guayabillo, indicating that its variations may have played a role in how guayabillo was affected by the invasive guava, particularly in relation to the timing of guava introduction to the Galápagos Islands.
title: Local exclusion and regional decline of an endemic Galápagos tree species (Psidium galapageium) by an invasive relative (P. guajava)

finding: The rs1399200 SNP was identified as a regulatory element involved in the gene interaction between ACE2 and VPS13C, contributing to the regulation of genes associated with inflammatory responses.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The rs6632680 SNP was associated with the regulation of PHKA2, demonstrating significant interactions with ACE2 and highlighting its role in trans-regulatory processes.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: Significant minor allele frequency biases were observed for rs714205 across multiple populations, indicating selection pressure and an association with regulatory regions of ACE2 affecting PIR.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The rs4646142 SNP displayed significant association with regulatory regions of the CA5B gene; further, it was implicated in hypertension and related cardiovascular conditions.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The rs2285666 SNP was shown to alter binding sites for transcription factors, with associations established for hypertension and diverse ethnic impacts.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The rs2106809 SNP influenced transcription factor binding, linked to inflammatory responses and demonstrated a significant association with hypertension and myocardial infarction risk.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was part of identified cis-regulatory elements within ACE2 that directly implicated in the regulation of CA5B, reinforcing the connection of genetic regulation and respiratory mechanisms.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The SNP rs1023574 was identified as having a common local adaptation signature on chromosome 23 across RAN, SIM, and GEL breeds. It showed significant multivariate and univariate associations with membership in specific ecoregions, despite not being individually significant with any environmental variable. This suggests its adaptive benefits are linked to a combination of environmental factors.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and environmental adaptation in US beef cattle populations

finding: The variant rs4830974 was associated with lower basophil percentages among carriers, indicating a potential weak relationship. Moreover, there was speculation that coding variants in ACE2 might offer a protective effect against hypertension, consistent with the known relationship between the ACE gene and human blood pressure.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: This low-frequency intronic variant was nominally associated with eosinophilic esophagitis in an independent dataset, suggesting a potential predisposition for individuals carrying coding variants in ACE2 to develop gastro-oesophageal reflux disease with oesophagitis.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The damaging variant chrX:15600857:A:G was rare or absent in most populations but had an allele frequency of 0.1-0.2% in those with African ancestry. It directly affected a SARS-CoV-2-interacting amino acid, implying a variance that could influence susceptibility to COVID-19.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The eQTL variant rs181603331 was found to be associated with a significant decrease in ACE2 expression (log2 A<sub>FC</sub>=-1.6), indicating its role in regulatory mechanisms pertaining to ACE2 levels in the airway epithelium.
title: Type 2 and interferon inflammation strongly regulate SARS-CoV-2 related gene expression in the airway epithelium

finding: The study identified that the SNP rs12092652 is associated with the activation of the NRF2 and oxidative stress response in immune-regulatory cancer-associated fibroblasts across various carcinoma types. This implies a significant role of this SNP in modulating the stress response within the tumor microenvironment, particularly influencing cancer cell interactions and survival mechanisms.
title: Mapping the tumor stress network reveals dynamic shifts in the stromal oxidative stress response

finding: This SNP had been identified as regulating the expression of VPS13C, which encodes vacuolar protein sorting-associated protein 13C. It was part of long-distance trans-regulatory interactions, indicating a role in the ACE2 locus.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was associated with the regulation of PHKA2, a gene encoding phosphorylase kinase regulatory subunit alpha 2. It was implicated in inter-TAD trans-acting interactions within the ACE2 locus.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was found to tag regulatory sites associated with PIR. It displayed significant bias in minor allele frequencies across diverse populations and suggested selection acting on the locus.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was detected at a regulatory site impacting CA5B expression. It showed significant selection towards the reference allele and was previously linked to various cardiovascular conditions.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP altered potential transcription factor binding sites, specifically impacting HNF1 and Ncx motifs. It was associated with regulatory elements affecting CA5B, with links to hypertension and diabetes.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP also affected transcription factor binding, altering a CEBPB motif. It was previously associated with impacts on hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: This SNP was noted for its role in regulating CA5B within the ACE2 locus. It was adjacent to CTCF binding sites and contributed to the regulation of ACE2 expression.
title: A transcription regulatory network within the ACE2 locus may promote a pro-viral environment for SARS-CoV-2 by modulating expression of host factors

finding: The archaic allele (A) of the rs111811311 polymorphism in the TKTL1 gene was identified among 62 carriers in the UK Biobank study. Despite previous proposals linking this missense change to significant impacts on human/Neandertal brain differences, the study found no observable deviations in relevant anatomical brain measures or cognitive traits among carriers. A substantial proportion of carriers also held college/university degrees, suggesting no detrimental phenotypic consequences associated with this archaic allele.
title: Evaluating the effects of archaic protein-altering variants in living human adults

finding: The SNP rs1204041, located in the intronic region of the AR gene, was identified as an African-specific association with androgenetic alopecia. It showed a high allele frequency of 0.488 in Africa while being almost absent in European (0.002) and East Asian (0.000) populations.
title: Uncovering the genetic architecture and evolutionary roots of androgenetic alopecia in African men

finding: The SNP D355N [rs961360700] was identified as a variant that restricts the interaction between the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 and ACE2, thereby limiting the susceptibility to infection in both in vitro and in vivo models. This finding suggested that this polymorphism could modulate human susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2.
title: Susceptibilities of human ACE2 genetic variants in coronavirus infection

finding: The variant rs41300872, which results in a p.Gly197Arg change, showed significant association with male infertility, with an odds ratio of 1.77 and a p-value of 0.002. This finding was part of the study exploring the role of TEX13B in male infertility in a cohort of 628 infertile men.
title: TEX13B is important for germ cell development and male fertility

finding: The rare variant rs775429506, causing a p.Gly237Glu substitution, was identified exclusively in two men with non-obstructive azoospermia (NOA). This finding contributed to the understanding of genetic factors associated with male infertility.
title: TEX13B is important for germ cell development and male fertility

finding: The SNP rs34729789 was identified as a significant hemizygous, X-linked G>A variant associated with a male infant who presented with microcephaly, seizures, polycystic kidney disease, and end-stage renal failure. Whole exome sequencing and pedigree analyses confirmed this variant's relevance, linking it to conditions related to ciliopathies, although the function of the EFHC2 gene, which the SNP affects, remains largely unknown.
title: Ancient eukaryotic protein interactions illuminate modern genetic traits and disorders

finding: The risk 'A' allele showed significantly decreased transcriptional activity compared to the normal 'G' allele in PC-3 cells, representing a negative influence on gene expression.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: The risk allele presented significantly lower transcriptional activity when compared to the normal allele in LNCaP cells, indicating a negative regulatory effect.
title: A dinucleotide tag-based parallel reporter gene assay method

finding: The rs12688220 locus, particularly the TT variant, was identified as a risk factor for chronic pancreatitis in North American patients of European ancestry. This high-risk genotype was associated with increased severity of chronic pancreatitis, suggesting that individuals with the homozygous CLDN2 genotype were at the greatest risk, a phenomenon that was further amplified by alcohol consumption.
title: Claudin-2 limits pancreatitis development through regulating tight junction-controlled pancreatic ductal transport

finding: The G6PD SNP rs1050828 was identified as a common African variant, exclusively observed in donors of African descent, linked to pyruvate levels. This association underscores its relevance to ethnicity-specific metabolic pathways in RBCs.
title: Biological and Genetic Determinants of Glycolysis: Phosphofructokinase Isoforms Boost Energy Status of Stored Red Blood Cells and Transfusion Outcomes

finding: The SNP rs142984500 was associated with increased RBD-ACE2 binding affinity, indicating a potential genetic susceptibility to COVID-19. This variant was prevalent in Europeans and linked to the binding capacity of ACE2 with SARS-CoV-2, suggesting increased risk of infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs4646116, known to have a significant impact on the binding affinity between ACE2 and the SARS-CoV-2 RBD, was found to increase the binding affinity, suggesting that individuals carrying this polymorphism may exhibit greater susceptibility to the virus.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs2285666 was reported to be associated with increased infection risk and mortality in COVID-19 patients, highlighting its role as a genetic factor influencing disease severity and susceptibility.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs759579097, associated with ACE2 polymorphism, was suggested to have protective effects against SARS-CoV-2 by decreasing binding affinity to the RBD, thus potentially lowering susceptibility to infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs758278442 was identified as responsible for reduced binding affinity between RBD and ACE2, implying that individuals with this polymorphism might be less susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The SNP rs146676783, similar to rs758278442, was reported to decrease the binding affinity of ACE2 to the SARS-CoV-2 RBD, suggesting a reduced risk of infection in carriers of this allele.
title: Differences between Omicron SARS-CoV-2 RBD and other variants in their ability to interact with cell receptors and monoclonal antibodies

finding: The study referenced by Sakai et al. in 2020 indicated that SNP rs12010204 was associated with a cytological model of B-Cell/Macrophage Biphenotypic Cell Hodgkin Lymphoma in Ganp-Transgenic mice. This finding suggested a link between the genetic variant and disease processes related to lymphomas, highlighting its potential significance in the context of GANP-related pathways.
title: Peripheral neuropathy linked mRNA export factor GANP reshapes gene regulation in human motor neurons

finding: The SNP rs73635825 (S19P) was identified as the most relevant variant in terms of interaction with the SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein, being the most frequent among the ACE2 variants (0.06% of the population). This SNP was located in the ACE2/Spike binding region and received significant support from GBPM analysis, suggesting its potential role in influencing susceptibility to COVID-19.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs143936283 (E329G) was identified as a very rare allele (0.0066%) in the European (non-Finnish) and Asian populations, located within the ACE2/Spike interaction interface. Although it was rare, its potential to alter binding affinity with the Spike protein was highlighted.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs766996587 (M82I) was categorized as a very rare variant (0.0066%) found in the African population. It was considered to potentially increase the affinity with Spike based on in silico predictions, although it lacked direct clinical significance.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs146676783 (E37K) was noted for being more common in the Finnish population (0.03%) and was included in the analysis for its possible role in altering binding with SARS-CoV-2 Spike, albeit with no reported clinical implications.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs370610075 (G352V) was identified as a rare variant (0.007%) in the European (non-Finnish) population. Its potential impact on Spike binding was noted although it did not have any clinical significance reported.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs12010173 was related to variations in cone production in Stone Pine (Pinus pinea L.), indicating a genetic influence on reproductive performance and potentially linking to life history strategies in long-lived plants. It demonstrated a correlation with resource allocation patterns that affect both growth and reproductive outputs, aligning with the Trait-Resource-Life-History framework.
title: An integrative trait-based framework to infer resource budgets and life-histories of long lived plants

finding: The SNP rs6528024 was found to be significantly associated with delay discounting in a human GWAS, indicating its potential importance in understanding this behavioral trait. However, this study failed to replicate these findings in Heterogenous Stock rats, which may suggest species-specific genetic influences.
title: Genome-wide association study of delay discounting in Heterogenous Stock rats

finding: The SNP rs3088074, located in the ATRX gene, was validated in human induced pluripotent stem cells (hiPSCs) showing clonal and monoallelic expression. This validation indicated that the gene remained monoallelic across all hiPSC lines tested, regardless of their X-chromosome inactivation (XCI) status, highlighting its significance in studying XCI erosion.
title: Erosion of X-Chromosome Inactivation in female hiPSCs is heterogeneous and persists during differentiation

finding: This SNP, identified as a non-autosomal hit, had previously been linked to age of first sexual intercourse and educational attainment.
title: Genome-wide association study of occupational status and prestige identifies 106 genetic variants and defines their role for intergenerational status transmission and the life course

finding: The rs73635825 (S19P) allele of the hACE2 receptor was identified as potentially offering resistance or protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection due to a low affinity to the virus RBD region. This finding was significant in the context of assessing genetic factors influencing susceptibility to the virus.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The rs143936283 (E329G) allele of the hACE2 receptor was also found to provide some level of resistance or protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection, similarly attributed to its low affinity towards the virus RBD. This suggests that specific genetic variants may contribute to variations in individual susceptibility to COVID-19.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The study identified rs1059702 located in the IRAK1 gene as an allelic variant that could alter amino acid sequence. It served as a candidate for driving allelic enhancer activity in association with Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE).
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: This variant was associated with the HCFC1 gene and was recognized as a candidate allelic variant that alters amino acid sequences and is relevant to SLE risk.
title: Genome-wide discovery of SLE genetic risk variant allelic enhancer activity

finding: The SNP rs11091241 was identified as a positive and original finding related to the regulation of fucose linkages in cancer. Specifically, a study referenced that highlighted the contributions of various fucose linkages, including those mediated by B3GNT7, which are relevant in the context of colorectal cancer (CAC) and colitis.
title: Oxytocin alleviated colitis and colitis-associated colorectal tumorigenesis by targeting fucosylated MUC2

finding: In a study conducted by El-Hefnawy et al. in 2022, the SNP rs3853839 within the TLR7 gene was associated with increased susceptibility and severity of COVID-19 among middle-aged individuals without previous comorbidities. The research indicated that this polymorphism potentially influenced mRNA expression of TLR7, impacting the clinical outcomes of COVID-19.
title: The SARS-CoV-2 Spike S1 Protein Induces Global Proteomic Changes in ATII-Like Rat L2 Cells that are Attenuated by Hyaluronan

finding: The SNP rs12010227 was found to be relevant in targeting osteosarcoma with plasma-treated solutions, suggesting that it may also have implications in the context of CAP therapies for various cancer types, as discussed by Mateu-Sanz et al. in their research.
title: Epidermal Growth Factor potentiates EGFR(Y992/1173)-mediated therapeutic response of triple negative breast cancer cells to cold atmospheric plasma-activated medium

finding: The SNP rs392020 was associated with the gene SLC25A5, as it had a high posterior inclusion probability. This connection was established through integration of multiple gene prioritization methods, emphasizing its role in mitochondrial function, specifically related to mtDNA metabolism.
title: Genetic analysis of mitochondrial DNA copy number and associated traits identifies loci implicated in nucleotide metabolism, platelet activation, and megakaryocyte proliferation, and reveals a causal association of mitochondrial function with mortality

finding: The rs1050828 SNP, encoding G6PD+202T, showed significant differential effects in the context of severe malaria. In the analysis, the T allele was associated with protection in the 'severe malaria' sub-population (odds-ratio 0.71 [95% C.I. 0.57-0.88]), while it was linked to increased risk in the 'not severe malaria' sub-population (odds-ratio 1.30 [95% C.I. 1.00-1.70]). This indicated opposing effects of the G6PD deficiency, hypothesizing that such deficiency may contribute to misclassification as severe malaria due to severe anemia.
title: Improving statistical power in severe malaria genetic association studies by augmenting phenotypic precision

finding: This coding variant was strongly associated with total and direct bilirubin levels and linked to G6PD deficiency in African Americans, reaffirming its significant role in bilirubin metabolism.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: This coding variant was associated with HbA1c in South Asians, presenting implications for diabetes management due to its connection with G6PD deficiency.
title: Analyses of Biomarker Traits in Diverse UK Biobank Participants Identify Associations Missed by European-centric Analysis Strategies

finding: The rs4646116 SNP, predicting the p.Lys26Arg amino acid change, was encountered at polymorphic frequencies among various populations. It was found in 1.43% of Ashkenazi Jewish males (1 in 70) and in lower frequencies among non-Finnish European males (0.58%, or 1 in 172). Additionally, the SNP was noted to occur at very low frequencies in East Asian populations, with significant implications for ACE2 binding affinity and potential influence on SARS-CoV-2 progression.
title: ACE 2 Coding Variants: A Potential X-linked Risk Factor for COVID-19 Disease

finding: The SNP rs12010146 was associated with neurocognitive decline following cranial irradiation. Specifically, it was found to be linked to the regulatory mechanisms involved in cognitive functions affected by radiotherapy, highlighting its potential relevance in understanding vulnerability to cognitive impairment in patients undergoing radiation therapy.
title: PAK3 downregulation induces cognitive impairment following cranial irradiation

finding: The SNP rs5919432, located 71kb from the androgen receptor gene at Xq12, had a higher frequency of the risk-increasing T allele in MADCaP prostate cancer cases compared to controls (34.2% vs. 32.1%). Although originally identified in European populations, this study revealed similar risk effects in African populations.
title: A custom genotyping array reveals population-level heterogeneity for the genetic risks of prostate cancer and other cancers in Africa

finding: The M1V variant (rs3764880) of TLR8 was found to be associated with enhanced intracellular killing of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) in primary macrophages. This variant, common in Far Eastern populations, led to increased phagosomal acidification and enhanced inflammatory responses. Consequently, it was implicated in providing protection from pulmonary tuberculosis, as demonstrated through macrophage studies showing its impact on killing efficacy and overall immune response.
title: Phagosomal RNA sensing through TLR8 controls susceptibility to tuberculosis

finding: SNP rs2681646 was associated with variance of waist circumference at X-chromosome-wide significance in the UK Biobank dataset (p=9.5E-07) and showed a suggestive female-specific effect in the MESA dataset (p=0.048).
title: Analytical strategies to include the X-chromosome in variance heterogeneity analyses: evidence for trait-specific polygenic variance structure

finding: This missense variant changed a lysine at position 26 to arginine (K26R), enhancing binding affinity to SARS-CoV-2's S-protein RBD. It was very rare in East Asians and Africans but was common in Europeans (MAF=0.587%) and the Kuwaiti population (MAF=0.29%).
title: A comprehensive germline variant and expression analyses of ACE2, TMPRSS2 and SARS-CoV-2 activator FURIN genes from the Middle East: Combating SARS-CoV-2 with precision medicine

finding: The N720D variant was prevalent in Europeans (MAF=2.52%) and was associated with increased susceptibility to severe COVID-19 through potential TMPRSS2 activation, despite concerns about its distance from ACE2’s S-protein interaction site.
title: A comprehensive germline variant and expression analyses of ACE2, TMPRSS2 and SARS-CoV-2 activator FURIN genes from the Middle East: Combating SARS-CoV-2 with precision medicine

finding: The SNP rs12010146 was associated with neurocognitive decline following cranial irradiation as reported in the study by Pazzaglia et al. In this context, it related to mechanisms influencing cognitive dysfunction due to the actin cytoskeleton disruptions and PAK3 signaling pathways in response to ionizing radiation.
title: PAK3 downregulation induces cognitive impairment following cranial irradiation

finding: The variant rs7889328 created a transcription factor binding site (TFBS) for CTCFL in the promoter region of the gene RENBP. This alteration was significant for red blood cell (RBC) traits, particularly associated with RBC indices such as RBC count, RBC distribution width, and mean corpuscular volume. Conditional analyses indicated that alleles at rs7889328 accounted for the remaining association signal even after controlling for known GWAS variants at the same locus.
title: find-tfbs: a tool to identify functional non-coding variants associated with complex human traits using open chromatin maps and phased whole-genome sequences

finding: Associated findings indicated that rs311071 was mapped at 66.3 kb and 0.0007 cM distal to the PAB, suggesting its significance in narrowing down the PAB location.
title: Where is the boundary of the human pseudoautosomal region?

finding: This SNP was found to be the closest variant at only 246 bases distal to the Alu insertion marking the PAB. It was critical in redefining the boundaries of the PAB in light of historical recombination events.
title: Where is the boundary of the human pseudoautosomal region?

finding: The rs1322436793 SNP, causing a G305R mutation, was identified as damaging. It was characterized by a change that increased residue charge from neutral to positive, leading to potential repulsion of ligands and changes in structural conformation due to unusual torsion angles.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID
