finding: The rs1064794027 SNP resulted in a C182Y mutation which was found to disrupt hydrophobic interactions within the protein core due to the burial of the wild-type residue and introduction of a larger mutant residue.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033620 SNP induced a G114D mutation that caused structural disturbances as the substitution introduced larger residues affecting the protein's backbone conformation.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs193922347 SNP resulted in a Y105C mutation causing potential loss of external interactions, possibly altering protein functionality by disturbing molecular interactions critical for binding.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1293196743 SNP caused a Y91C mutation which introduced an empty space in the protein's core due to the smaller size of the mutant residue, possibly affecting its structural stability.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1057517950 SNP led to a W240R mutation that was associated with X-SCID, confirmed in a family study where a child displayed severe symptoms due to the mutation.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs869320659 SNP caused an R226C mutation implicated in X-SCID through maternal mosaicism, establishing a genetic mechanism for X-SCID pathology.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs869320658 SNP, resulting in an R224W mutation, was similarly validated through studies identifying its damaging effects associated with SCID.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033618 SNP responsible for a R222C mutation led to atypical SCID presentation. Despite normal lymphocyte counts, there was impaired signaling of cytokines.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: In the case of rs137852511, the L151P mutation was identified in a child, illustrating reversion in T-cell precursors leading to unique immune function outcomes.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033622 SNP caused a C115R mutation which resulted in atypical X-SCID with partially functional lymphocyte clones owing to mutation reversion in early T-cell precursors.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1057520293, resulting in L87P mutation, was noted in an X-SCID patient with a mild phenotype; mutation reversion influenced the delayed diagnosis.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs6318 variant had an extremely high MAF of 98.5% in Hong Kong Cantonese, which was linked to an increased likelihood of drug-related weight gain. This association was supported by findings from three different human studies.
title: HKG: An open genetic variant database of 205 Hong Kong Cantonese exomes

finding: This SNP resulted in a missense mutation (P212H) where Proline was changed to Histidine at position 212. It was found to have a significant deleterious effect on the GPC3 structure and function, contributing to the molecular basis of Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome which is characterized by pre- and postnatal overgrowth.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: This SNP caused a missense mutation (C65Y) where Cysteine was altered to Tyrosine at position 65. This alteration was identified as one of the most deleterious mutations affecting GPC3 protein stability and function, providing insights into their connection with overgrowth Syndrome.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: This SNP led to a missense mutation (R39C) transforming Arginine to Cysteine at position 39. It was highlighted as a crucial mutation with potential functional implications for GPC3, further linking it to the pathogenesis of overgrowth Syndrome.
title: Identification of novel key biomarkers in Simpson-Golabi-Behmel Syndrome: Evidence from bioinformatics analysis

finding: In a study published in 2017, it was found that the MAOA gene variant rs1137070 interacted with heroin addiction to alter the gray matter volume of the salience network. This suggests that individuals with certain genotypes at this SNP may have varying structural brain differences that could influence their susceptibility to heroin addiction, underscoring the importance of genetic factors in addiction-related behaviors.
title: The anterior insular cortex in the rat exerts an inhibitory influence over the loss of control of heroin intake and subsequent propensity to relapse

finding: The rs1322436793 (G305R) mutation was identified as novel and predicted to be damaging. The mutation caused a change in residue size and charge, which negatively affected protein structure by causing potential shape disturbances.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1064794027 (C182Y) mutation was deemed novel and damaging, with its mutant residue being too large to properly fit into the protein core, leading to a loss of hydrophobic interactions crucial for the protein's function.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs111033620 (G114D) mutation was identified as novel and damaging, similarly to rs1064794027, where the mutant residue's size and properties disrupted the essential structural integrity of the protein.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs193922347 (Y105C) mutation was recognized as novel and damaging, resulting in a smaller mutant residue that potentially lost important external interactions, thereby diminishing protein function.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The rs1293196743 (Y91C) mutation was reported as novel and damaging; the size of the mutant residue created an empty space in the protein core which negatively impacted the structural integrity.
title: Computational Analysis Revealed Five Novel Mutations in Human IL2RG gene Related to X-SCID

finding: The SNP rs12010226 was associated with the expression of cancer stem cell-like phenotypes in human medulloblastoma (MB) cell lines. This association was derived from research that investigated the behavior of MB cells in response to various treatments, including rosmarinic acid, and its effects on stemness and proliferation.
title: Modulation of Viability, Proliferation, and Stemness by Rosmarinic Acid in Medulloblastoma Cells: Involvement of HDACs and EGFR

finding: The SNP rs12010130 was linked to findings in the context of gammadelta T cell immunotherapy, where its influence was studied in relation to the cytokine pre-treatment of IL-2/IL-12/18. This SNP was associated with enhanced anti-tumoral functions of gammadelta T cells, which demonstrated significant direct killing abilities and induced senescence in cancer cells.
title: IL-12/18/21 pre-activation enhances the anti-tumor efficacy of expanded γδT cells and overcomes resistance to anti-PD-L1 treatment

finding: The missense variant rs148051057 located in the <italic>RGN</italic> gene was associated with gluconate levels, supporting previous associations.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The rs112701110 variant near the <italic>MID1IP1</italic> gene was associated with guanidino and acetamido levels, with novel associations to branched-chain amino acid metabolism.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The variant rs11553055 associated with guaiacol sulfate linked with <italic>ASMTL</italic>, reflecting a solid association.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The SNP rs2071223 was associated with the gene Bruton tyrosine kinase (BTK) in male lymphocytes, with a reported significance (p = 0.005). This finding underscored the male-specific role of BTK in the context of severe COVID-19, linking the genetic variant to immune response differences between sexes.
title: Multimodal Single-Cell Omics Analysis of COVID-19 Sex Differences in Human Immune Systems

finding: The SNP rs190509934 was associated with COVID-19 infection risk through its effect on ACE2 expression levels. RegulomeDB indicated its involvement with multiple DNase-seq peaks in lung-related biosamples, hypothesizing that ACE2 expression may be regulated by CEBP as indicated by its overlap with DNase footprints in the upstream promoter region of ACE2.
title: Annotating and prioritizing human non-coding variants with RegulomeDB

finding: The SNP rs4898 was studied in the context of its association with early-onset preeclampsia and placenta weight. The research indicated that the TIMP1 gene polymorphism (rs4898) had significant effects on the development of early-onset preeclampsia, thereby serving as a potential biomarker for this condition.
title: Single-cell transcriptomic analysis of immune cell dynamics in the healthy human endometrium

finding: The SNP rs12010210 was associated with the potential therapeutic benefits of metformin in high-grade glioma, as discussed in the study by Mazurek et al. (2020), which argued for metformin's role in glioma treatment.
title: A combination of Metformin and Epigallocatechin Gallate Potentiates Glioma Chemotherapy in vivo

finding: The rs6152 variant was linked to a susceptibility to prostate cancer, showing interactions with an enhancer that regulates the expression of the AR gene, a critical regulator in cancer.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs201194898 in the NPR region exhibited significantly higher minor allele frequencies (MAFs) in females compared to males across all five super-populations, with sdMAF p-values extremely low (<1e-200) indicating strong sex differences.
title: Major sex differences in allele frequencies for X chromosome variants in the 1000 Genomes Project data

finding: Similar to rs201194898, the SNP rs6634333 in the NPR region also demonstrated a significant excess of heterozygous females across super-populations, with genome-wide significant HWE testing p-values, suggesting substantial sdMAF.
title: Major sex differences in allele frequencies for X chromosome variants in the 1000 Genomes Project data

finding: The SNP rs34507903, located at position X:21940733A/G, was identified in the gene SMS, which encodes the enzyme spermine synthase. This finding was notable as it demonstrated biallelic expression of the gene in female trophoblasts, suggesting that sex differences in polyamine metabolism related to escape from X chromosome inactivation had implications for placental function and could influence pregnancy disorders like pre-eclampsia.
title: Placental polyamines regulate acetyl-coA and histone acetylation in a sex-specific manner

finding: The SNP rs1128363, located at position X:48894188G/A within the gene TIMM17B, served as a negative control for XCI effects, as its expression did not significantly vary by sex. This finding allowed for the comparison against the SMS SNP and aided in demonstrating the specific metabolic alterations in female placentas associated with fetal sex differences.
title: Placental polyamines regulate acetyl-coA and histone acetylation in a sex-specific manner

finding: The SNP rs12010146 was identified in the research of Pazzaglia et al. (2020), which explored neurocognitive decline following radiotherapy, particularly its mechanisms and therapeutic implications. This study suggested a potential genetic association with cognitive decline linked to radiotherapy, though specific details on the exact effects of this SNP were not extensively defined in the abstract provided.
title: Fractionated brain irradiation profoundly reduces hippocampal immature neuron numbers without affecting spontaneous behavior and cognition in mice

finding: The SNP rs6323 was associated with variations in aggressive behavior as linked to the functional polymorphism of the monoamine oxidase-A gene (MAOA). The study indicated that genetic mutations within MAOA, including rs6323, had implications for the tendency towards anger-driven aggression. This finding suggested that such genetic variations could serve as indicators for future management and screening strategies for aggressive behaviors.
title: Identification of Six novel missense single nucleotide polymorphisms in MAOA gene predisposing to aggressive behavior. Bioinformatics study

finding: The HTR2C rs1414334 C/C genotype was associated with significant weight gain during olanzapine treatment compared to T carriers, supporting its role in weight modulation during antipsychotic therapy.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The rs2074192 TT genotype was associated with significantly higher expression of ACE2 mRNA and ACE2 protein in placental organoids, and individuals with this genotype displayed a 23-fold increased risk of small-for-gestational-age (SGA) newborns. This SNP was shown to alter the ACE2:ACE expression ratio and influence placental development negatively despite an overall increase in ACE2 expression, indicating its important role in pregnancy health.
title: Genetically edited human placental organoids cast new light on the role of ACE2 in placental development

finding: The SNP rs73635825 (S19P) was associated with a level of resistance or protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection due to its low affinity to the virus RBD region. This genetic variant was noted for its impact on the ability of the ACE2 receptor to interact with the virus, suggesting a potential role in reduced susceptibility.
title: SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations, ACE2 genetic polymorphism, and stability of the virus-receptor complex: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: Similarly, the SNP rs143936283 (E329G) was found to confer protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection as well, attributed to its low affinity for the virus RBD region. This connection highlighted the importance of ACE2 receptor genetic variants in influencing individual susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2.
title: SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations, ACE2 genetic polymorphism, and stability of the virus-receptor complex: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The SNP rs73635825 caused an S19P amino acid variant and was found to be the most frequent variant in the population at 0.06%. It was significant for its interaction with the SARS-CoV-2 Spike protein, with a GBPM score supporting its key interaction role.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs143936283 resulted in an E329G amino acid change and was categorized as a very rare allele at 0.0066% in the European (non-Finnish) Asian population. Its potential role in altering the binding affinity with Spike was highlighted.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs766996587, causing an M82I amino acid change, was also noted as a very rare allele found at a frequency of 0.0066% in the African population, with predictions suggesting it could increase the affinity with Spike.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs146676783, which caused an E37K amino acid change, was reported to be more common in the Finnish population (0.03%) and has been predicted to decrease the binding affinity with Spike.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: The SNP rs370610075 led to a G352V amino acid variant and was observed at a frequency of 0.007% in the European (non-Finnish) population. Its potential effects on the Spike affinity were also noted.
title: Structural Genetics of circulating variants affecting the SARS-CoV-2 Spike / human ACE2 complex

finding: SNP rs142932029 in FTSJ1 showed the top association with facial module 28, achieving a remarkable p-value of 1.59 × 10⁻¹⁴. This association highlighted the significant impact of low-frequency coding variants on facial shape phenotypes.
title: Impact of low-frequency coding variants on human facial shape

finding: The rs6152 variant in the AR gene showed a significant association with prostate cancer susceptibility and formed contacts with an active enhancer that regulates AR expression during cancer progression.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The rs73635825 (S19P) allele of the hACE2 receptor was reported to potentially confer some level of resistance or protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection due to its low affinity to the virus RBD region.
title: SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations, ACE2 genetic polymorphism, and stability of the virus-receptor complex: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The rs143936283 (E329G) allele of the hACE2 receptor may also offer resistance against SARS-CoV-2 infection, likely due to a similar mechanism of reduced binding affinity to the virus's RBD.
title: SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations, ACE2 genetic polymorphism, and stability of the virus-receptor complex: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The SNP rs7886851 in the <italic>MAGED1</italic> gene was found to be significantly associated with the transition from first cocaine use to cocaine use disorder (CUD). This association was corroborated by a Kaplan–Meier survival analysis that yielded a log-rank p value of 0.002, indicating its relevance in determining addiction risk.
title: Histone H2A monoubiquitination in the thalamus regulates cocaine effects and addiction risk

finding: The SNP rs6614508 in the <italic>MAGED1</italic> gene also showed a significant association with the transition from first cocaine use to CUD. Similar to rs7886851, the Kaplan–Meier survival analysis demonstrated significance with a log-rank p value of 0.002, reinforcing its potential as a marker for addiction progression.
title: Histone H2A monoubiquitination in the thalamus regulates cocaine effects and addiction risk

finding: This low-frequency intronic variant (MAF 1%) was nominally associated with eosinophilic esophagitis in an independent dataset, showing a predisposition for those with coding variants.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: This variant was identified as the most common among those affecting SARS-CoV-2 interaction, with a frequency of approximately 0.5% in multiple populations and changing an amino acid adjacent to a SARS-CoV-2-interacting amino acid, although it was not predicted to be damaging.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: This variant was rare or absent in most populations, but noted to have an allele frequency of 0.1-0.2% in individuals of African ancestry, affecting a SARS-CoV-2 interactive amino acid and predicted to be damaging.
title: Revealing variants in SARS-CoV-2 interaction domain of ACE2 and loss of function intolerance through analysis of >200,000 exomes

finding: The analysis revealed that the rs952836 locus was part of the shared interval among affected individuals carrying the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation in the FALS5 and FALS14 families, indicating a founder effect. This supported the concept that the mutation is pathogenic for ALS and FTD.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The rs6423133 locus was also identified within the interval shared by affected individuals with the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation, confirming its association with the genetic predisposition to ALS and FTD in the examined families.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs1978124 was found to have a differential frequency distribution in various population groups, particularly in the African (AFR), American (AMR), and South Asian (SAS) groups, indicating significant population-level variations in the ACE2 gene expression which may impact COVID-19 susceptibility.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: Similar to rs1978124, the SNP rs2106809 was also associated with differential frequency across population groups, suggesting its role in modulating ACE2 expression and consequently the host entry mechanism for SARS-CoV-2.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: The variant R625X (p.Arg625Ter) in the CACNA1F gene was identified as the only common pathogenic alteration in three siblings presenting with X-linked incomplete congenital stationary night blindness and immune dysfunction. The mutation was not found in large population databases, underscoring its rarity and pathogenic nature.
title: Mutation of an L-Type Calcium Channel Gene Leads to a Novel Human Primary Cellular Immunodeficiency

finding: The rs1050828 SNP, which encodes G6PD+202T, was found to have significant differential effects across the severe malaria and not severe malaria sub-populations in females. The T allele was associated with protection in the 'severe malaria' sub-population, showing an odds ratio of 0.71 [95% C.I. 0.57-0.88], while in the 'not severe malaria' sub-population, it was associated with increased risk (odds ratio of 1.30 [95% C.I. 1.00-1.70]). This indicated opposing effects for the two sub-populations.
title: Improving statistical power in severe malaria genetic association studies by augmenting phenotypic precision

finding: The SNP rs1023574 was identified as a significant locus associated with environmental adaptation in the Forested Mountains ecoregion across multiple populations. It showed univariate and multivariate associations with ecoregion membership and was linked to the pseudogene LOC782044 and the gene KHDRBS2, previously noted in adaptation studies of livestock.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and environmental adaptation in US beef cattle

finding: The SNP rs11091220 was associated with the gene p21 (Cip1/Waf1/CDKN1A), which is known to play a significant role in cell cycle regulation and differentiation. This connection supported the notion that genetic variations linked to hibernation could influence pathways related to cell cycle arrest and other cellular functions important during the hibernation process in mammals.
title: The meadow jumping mouse genome and transcriptome suggest mechanisms of hibernation

finding: The missense variant rs148051057 in the RGN gene was related to gluconate levels, with a significant replication p-value.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: Near the MID1IP1 gene, rs112701110 was associated with guanidino and acetamido levels, and additionally linked to novel associations with amino acid metabolism including leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: Located in the VSIG4 gene, rs867460874 had significant associations with long-chain monounsaturated fatty acids, with a notable replication p-value.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: Associated with gualacol sulfate, rs11553055 was found in the ASMTL gene, indicating its role in metabolic processes.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The study demonstrated that single-cell DAF-seq enabled haplotype phasing for the bottom strand reads of rs56269549, which is a C/T heterozygous variant associated with the UBA1 transcriptional start sites. The data revealed that specific transcription start sites were selectively accessible on distinct haplotypes, allowing for a better understanding of gene regulation at this locus.
title: Deaminase-assisted single-molecule and single-cell chromatin fiber sequencing

finding: The SNP rs112977454 was identified as a highly segregated eQTL in African populations, with a CADD score of 9.018, making it a strong candidate for influencing the regulation of the JPX gene, which is involved in X chromosome inactivation. This variant's absence in non-African populations pointed to its potential role in population-specific adaptations and regulatory changes linked to transcription factor binding sites in the HUVEC cell line.
title: Chromosome X-wide analysis of positive selection in human populations: from common and private signals to selection impact on inactivated genes and enhancers-like signatures

finding: The SNP rs5913773 was identified as replicating in a previous study, contributing to the 7 associations found for RBC. This finding highlighted its significance in the genetic analysis of red blood cell traits.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs5960376 also replicated in a previous study, being one of the 5 novel associations identified for RBC. This suggested a potential role of this SNP in modifying red blood cell characteristics.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: SNP rs1339116 was classified as novel and was located intragenically within a gene near the MAGEB gene family, indicating a possible role in HDL levels based on limited supporting evidence in mice.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs10126777 was noted to be a novel association for BMD, though it was previously recognized for being near the TBX22 gene, which has connections to bone formation and cleft palate.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The SNP rs189438396 was identified as upstream of the PTCHD1 gene with a significant p-value of 0.0019, indicating its importance in the context of MCH associations, despite being a novel finding.
title: Light-speed whole genome association testing and prediction via Approximate Message Passing

finding: The study identified the rs12688220 locus (TT variant) as a risk variant for pancreatitis, primarily due to its proximity to the CLDN2 gene. It was noted that approximately 25% of pancreatitis patients carried the high-risk TT allele, which was linked to increased risk for more severe pancreatitis outcomes.
title: Claudin-2 limits pancreatitis development through regulating tight junction-controlled pancreatic ductal transport

finding: The rs73635825 (S19P) allele of the hACE2 receptor was reported to potentially offer a level of resistance against SARS-CoV-2 infection due to a low affinity for the virus RBD region. This finding indicates that genetic variants in the ACE2 receptor may be associated with protection from infection.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: The rs143936283 (E329G) allele of the hACE2 receptor was also found to confer some level of resistance/protection against SARS-CoV-2 infection by exhibiting a low affinity for the virus RBD region. This observation reinforces the notion that ACE2 genetic polymorphism may influence susceptibility or resistance to SARS-CoV-2.
title: A computational approach to evaluate the combined effect of SARS-CoV-2 RBD mutations and ACE2 receptor genetic variants on infectivity: The COVID-19 host-pathogen nexus

finding: SNP rs142932029 in FTSJ1 showed a top association with facial module 28, evidencing a very strong statistical significance (p-value = 1.59 × 10⁻¹⁴). This indicates that this particular SNP is strongly associated with variations in specific facial phenotypes.
title: Impact of low-frequency coding variants on human facial shape

finding: The study confirmed that placental organoids with the ACE2 rs2074192 TT genotype exhibited significantly higher ACE2 mRNA and protein levels compared to CC and CT genotype organoids. Additionally, TT organoids demonstrated altered ACE2:ACE expression ratios, which were linked to impaired growth and symmetry, indicating the SNP's role in enhancing ACE2 expression while also contributing to developmental challenges.
title: Genetically edited placental organoids cast new light on the role of ACE2 in placental development

finding: The ITM2A rs1751094 polymorphism was associated with autoimmune thyroid disease in a study involving Korean pediatric patients, suggesting potential links to immune-related pathways relevant to IBD.
title: Identification of differentially expressed genes and enriched pathways in inflammatory bowel disease using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The G>C substitution (SNP rs138166791) in the penultimate position of pre-miR-890 significantly lowered the cleavage efficiency by DROSHA. This decreased the levels of both mature miR-890-5p and miR-890-3p, leading to altered miRNA biogenesis and specificity of target recognition.
title: Somatic mutations in miRNA genes in lung cancer – potential functional consequences of non-coding sequence variants

finding: SNP rs3788853, located approximately 2 kb upstream of the TSS of XPNPEP2, exhibited a strong increase in SuRE activity in HepG2 cells by about 5-fold. This SNP has been previously identified as affecting enhancer activity for XPNPEP2, supporting its functional relevance in gene regulation.
title: Systematic identification of human SNPs affecting regulatory element activity

finding: This SNP was associated with schizophrenia in a Han Chinese population and systemic lupus erythematosus in a European population, at genome-wide significance level of P < 5×10−8. It was located near the RENBP gene, which was part of the age-by-sex-associated genetic loci.
title: An epigenome-wide association study of sex-specific chronological ageing

finding: The SNP rs1978124 was identified as having a differential frequency distribution across global population groups, particularly showing a uniform distribution in the European (EUR) and East Asian (EAS) sub-populations. Its presence in intron 1 of the ACE2 gene suggested a strong enhancer activity correlated with higher expression levels of ACE2, which could potentially facilitate ACE2 homo-dimerization associated with SARS-CoV-2 entry mechanisms.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: Similar to rs1978124, rs2106809 also indicated differential frequency distribution across populations, predominantly appearing uniform within EUR and EAS sub-populations. Its location in ACE2 gene's intron 1 suggested regulatory roles that could influence ACE2 expression linked to COVID-19 severity.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: The SNP rs12010052 was identified as relevant in the context of circulating extracellular vesicle microRNA serving as diagnostic biomarkers for early colorectal cancer. This finding emerged from a review conducted by Desmond et al., which highlighted the potential of extracellular vesicles in cancer diagnostics, supporting their use for early detection and prognosis.
title: In situ investigation of extracellular vesicles in viscous formulations: interplay of nanoparticle transport and nano rheology through interferometric light microscopy analysis

finding: The variant XEDAR R57K (rs1385699) was highlighted as a derived coding variant that exhibited significant differentiation among modern humans. It was computationally identified as a potential target of positive natural selection in East Asia, suggesting its role in influencing mammary gland differentiation and growth.
title: Ectodysplasin signaling via Xedar is required for mammary gland morphogenesis

finding: The variant p.Lys26Arg (rs4646116) was reported to enhance affinity for the SARS-CoV-2 Spike receptor binding domain with a calculated change in free energy (ΔΔG) of 0.26 ± 0.09 kcal mol<sup>−1</sup>. It was found to be predominant in the Ashkenazi Jewish (AF = 0.01) and European non-Finnish (AF = 0.006) cohorts. This enhancement in Spike binding suggested that carriers of this allele may have an increased susceptibility to SARS-CoV-2 infection or severe disease, impacting the epidemiology of Covid-19.
title: Missense variants in human ACE2 modify binding to SARS-CoV-2 Spike

finding: The variant rs139643362 was linked to X-linked hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy, with the only brain cell type match being oligodendrocytes. This was corroborated by results from the mouse brain atlas that indicated relevance to glia and Schwann cells from the dorsal root ganglion, aligning with literature that implicates this disease with a lack of myelination.
title: Fast searches of large collections of single cell data using scfind

finding: The G6PD Mediterranean mutation (rs5030868; G>A; p.S188F) was identified in three out of four Tylos-period Bahraini individuals. This mutation was associated with malaria resistance and was estimated to have risen in frequency in Eastern Arabia from 5-6 thousand years ago, coinciding with the onset of agriculture in the region. The study also highlighted that none of the ancient Lebanese imputed samples carried this mutation, nor did Bronze Age Greek individuals, suggesting a unique prevalence of this allele in the Bahraini samples compared to other ancient populations.
title: Ancient genomes illuminate Eastern Arabian population history and adaptation against malaria

finding: The SNP rs11091285 was associated with K(Ca)3.1 channels, which conferred radioresistance in breast cancer cells. This finding highlighted the role of potassium channels in the tumor microenvironment, specifically how alterations in ion concentrations could influence cancer cell behavior.
title: Monitoring extracellular ion and metabolite dynamics with recombinant nanobody-fused biosensors

finding: The SNP rs878853698 was identified at the interface of the GLA-GLA complex, associated with Fabry disease. SWING predicted this variant to be disruptive of the enzymatic activity of alpha-galactosidase A in affected patients, marking a significant prediction aligned with the clinical presentation of the disease, where mutations lead to a functional deficiency of the enzyme. This variant was also labeled as 'likely pathogenic' in ClinVar and was overlooked by AlphaMissense.
title: Sliding Window INteraction Grammar (SWING): a generalized interaction language model for peptide and protein interactions

finding: The proxy SNP rs11094813 was used in place of rs12556975. It had an R-squared value indicating strong LD (CEU r² of 0.9 and GBR r² of 1) which suggested it could adequately represent the eQTL effects of the replaced SNP in the female cerebellum.
title: Analysis of expression Quantitative Trait Loci for NLGN4X in relation to language and neurodevelopmental function: an exploratory analysis using FUSION and GTEx workflows

finding: There was a confirmed identity-by-descent (IBD) segment identified over the UBQLN2 locus between all four affected individuals from the FALS5 and FALS14 families, which included the presence of rs952836. This finding indicated that the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation arose in a common founder and suggested a strong genetic linkage to ALS and FTD in the studied families.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: Similar to rs952836, rs6423133 was part of an identified IBD segment over the UBQLN2 locus in affected individuals from the FALS5 and FALS14 families. The presence of this SNP further confirmed the founder effect of the UBQLN2 p.T487I mutation, indicating its pathogenic role in ALS/FTD.
title: Hippocampal protein aggregation signatures fully distinguish pathogenic and wildtype UBQLN2 in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

finding: The SNP rs12010226 was linked to the expression of factors involved in the p21 signaling pathway, contributing to cell cycle arrest in medulloblastoma cells. This finding was particularly relevant in the context of increased CDKN1A/p21 expression and its role in reducing the proliferative rate of cancer cells.
title: Modulation of Viability, Proliferation, and Stemness by Rosmarinic Acid in Medulloblastoma Cells: Involvement of HDACs and EGFR

finding: The variant rs2239464, located at Xq28 within the MeCP2 gene, was associated with reduced cortical surface area specifically in males. This association was confirmed in two independent datasets, highlighting a sex-specific effect where females, benefiting from a second copy of the MeCP2 gene, did not exhibit this reduction. This finding suggested that the protective effect of having two copies of the gene in females may shield them from the negatives associated with this common variant, underscoring the gene's role in sex differences related to cortical surface area variability.
title: Sex differences in Variability of Brain Structure Across the Lifespan

finding: The variant rs6641874 was identified as a top variant in the BBJ + UKB meta-analysis and was associated with lymphocyte counts. The effect sizes were consistently larger in females than in males, suggesting a significant female/male effect size ratio in relation to lymphocyte counts. This variant was part of the analysis that linked the PRKX gene locus with cannabinoid-related lymphocyte activities, indicating the possibility that XCI escape mechanisms could contribute to sex differences in immune responses.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The variant rs6641601 was noted as the top variant in the eQTL analysis specific to monocytes. Like rs6641874, it also demonstrated a correlation with lymphocyte counts. The analyses highlighted differences in effect sizes between sexes, with a stronger influence observed in females, further reinforcing the notion of distinct genotype-phenotype associations based on sex, particularly in immune cell activities.
title: Quantification of the escape from X chromosome inactivation with the million cell-scale human single-cell omics datasets reveals heterogeneity of escape across cell types and tissues

finding: The SNP rs140385304 was found to be 153kb centromeric to the Cas9 cut site in an embryo containing a chromosome X fragment. This SNP was associated with a break at the centromere, resulting in a significant loss of more than 1 Mb of genomic DNA.
title: DNA Double Strand Breaks cause chromosome loss through sister chromatid tethering in human embryos

finding: The SNP rs56355347 was located at 41bp telomeric of the Cas9 cut site. It showed a detectable signal in a male embryo, where all 8 cells exhibited reciprocal whole and segmental chromosome changes, indicating that the cut site was preserved through at least three cell divisions over three days.
title: DNA Double Strand Breaks cause chromosome loss through sister chromatid tethering in human embryos

finding: The SNP rs11091220 was related to the expression of p21, a protein implicated in cell cycle regulation; its expression levels were influenced by benzidine exposure in UMUC-3 cells, linking this SNP to pathways affecting cell differentiation and cancer therapy.
title: Benzidine Induces Proliferation of UMUC3 Bladder Cancer Cells Through Activation of ERK5 Pathway

finding: SNP rs6151 was associated with the PKTTS race and mapped near QTLs related to leaf rust resistance, indicating its potential significance in breeding.
title: Identification of novel leaf rust seedling resistance loci in Iranian bread wheat germplasm using genome-wide association mapping

finding: The common variant rs1050828 (p.Val98Met) in the G6PD gene was associated with a decrease in HbA1c levels. It showed a reduction of -0.88% in hemizygous males and -0.34% in heterozygous females, explaining 23% of HbA1c variance in African-Americans. The association was significant across different cohorts, evidencing its importance in precision medicine for diabetes diagnosis.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The rare G6PD variant rs76723693 (p.Leu353Pro) was found to lower HbA1c by -0.98% in hemizygous males and -0.46% in heterozygous females. This finding suggested significant associations with HbA1c and indicated the potential impact of rare variants on diabetes diagnoses, particularly in African-American populations.
title: Impact of rare and common genetic variants on diabetes diagnosis by hemoglobin A1c in multi-ancestry cohorts: The Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine Program

finding: The G>C substitution in the penultimate position of the 3p passenger strand of hsa-miR-890 significantly lowered the cleavage efficiency by DROSHA, consequently decreasing the levels of both mature miR-890-5p and passenger miR-890-3p. This illustrates how mutations can impair miRNA processing and subsequent expression.
title: Pan-Cancer analysis of somatic mutations in miRNA genes

finding: The rs6152 SNP, found within the AR gene, showed a high association with prostate cancer susceptibility and was involved in chromatin interactions with an enhancer, implicating it in disease progression.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs2272737 was identified as the causal variant for 81 out of 97 phenotype associations within Cluster 1. This cluster related to properties of white matter tracts in the cerebrum and the variant was located near the gene FAM58A, associated with the X-linked syndrome STAR, which has notable brain variations.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs1894299 was associated with 96 imaging-derived phenotypes (IDPs) and was previously noted in a GWAS of Type 2 diabetes. It is located within the gene DUSP9, related to health conditions and specifically insulin resistance.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs644138 was the top variant in Cluster 3, associated with local brain volume in the occipital lobe, and was located in the SPRY3 gene, an eQTL for multiple genes linked to various neurodevelopmental disorders.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs12843772 served as the top variant in Cluster 4, linked to grey matter volume in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex and was near the gene ZIC3, associated with body pattern formation and relevant developmental disorders.
title: Enhanced Brain Imaging Genetics in UK Biobank

finding: The TIMP-1 gene polymorphism rs6609533 was associated with type 2 diabetes risk, indicating its potential impact on the disease's progression.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Underlying Mechanisms in Cystic Fibrosis and its Associated Complications Based on Bioinformatics Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The variant rs6152 was highlighted in the context of assessing early-onset hair loss risk. The study noted that individuals could query this SNP to determine their genetic predisposition to alopecia, demonstrating its clinical relevance in evaluating baldness risk among males.
title: Towards a new standard in genomic data privacy: a realization of owner-governance

finding: This SNP, encoding a synaptic adhesion molecule involved in intellectual disability and autism, showed a significant association.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This SNP is downstream of GAGE1 and was associated with significant multivariate connectivity.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This SNP, associated with actin dynamics via MTMR8, demonstrated a significant multivariate association.
title: Genetic architecture of the white matter connectome of the human brain

finding: This SNP exhibited significant associations with membership of various ecoregions across all populations (RAN, SIM, GEL). Specifically, it was linked to the Forested Mountains ecoregion and demonstrated significant associations with environmental variables such as temperature and humidity, indicating its role in local adaptation.
title: Powerful detection of polygenic selection and evidence of environmental adaptation in US beef cattle

finding: The study reported that GABRA3 gene SNP rs4828696 had a significant association with a-tDCS responder categorisation, indicating that individuals with variant expression of this SNP were 3.5 times more likely to be categorized as responders compared to those with normal expression (p=0.023). Furthermore, there were significant increases in corticospinal excitability (CSE) after a-tDCS in the variant expression group, supporting its role in tDCS-induced cortical plasticity.
title: Can genetic polymorphisms predict response variability to anodal transcranial direct current stimulation of the primary motor cortex?

finding: significant association was noted for GABRA3 SNP rs1112122, where variant expression correlated with a 3-fold increase in the likelihood of being categorized as an a-tDCS responder compared to normal expression (OR=3.051, p=0.040). This suggests a considerable role in mediating the response to tDCS.
title: Can genetic polymorphisms predict response variability to anodal transcranial direct current stimulation of the primary motor cortex?

finding: The SNP rs1978124 was associated with differential frequency distribution across global populations, particularly showing higher variation in populations from AFR, AMR, and SAS groups. It was indicated to be located in the intron 1 of the ACE2 gene and involved in enhancer activity, affecting the expression of ACE2, which plays a role in SARS-CoV-2 binding.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: Similar to rs1978124, the SNP rs2106809 exhibited differential frequency distribution among global populations and was linked to the ACE2 gene's intron 1. Its enhancer region activity suggested it might influence ACE2 expression and the associated viral entry related to SARS-CoV-2.
title: ACE2 Homo-dimerization, Human Genomic variants and Interaction of Host Proteins Explain High Population Specific Differences in Outcomes of COVID19

finding: This SNP, rs1059702, was reported to have associations with risks regarding hematological traits, also achieving a VDA score of 0.7, indicating curation support for its disease link.
title: Comprehensive assessment of Indian variations in the druggable kinome landscape highlights distinct insights at the sequence, structure and pharmacogenomic stratum

finding: The SNP rs1137070 was found to interactively affect gray matter volume (GMV) in the salience network among heroin addiction patients. This interaction was significant in the context of heroin exposure, suggesting that genetic predispositions, as indicated by this SNP, may play a role in the structural brain changes observed in opioid use disorder.
title: Long-access heroin self-administration induces region specific reduction of grey matter volume and microglia reactivity in the rat

finding: Evidence suggested that the FoxP3 rs3761548 polymorphism could predict susceptibility to autoimmune diseases, which may be relevant in the context of inflammatory bowel diseases.
title: Identification of hub genes and key pathways in pediatric Crohn’s disease using next generation sequencing and bioinformatics analysis

finding: The SNP <italic>rs1718043</italic> at the <italic>DMD</italic> locus was associated with serum urate levels in the Japanese serum urate GWAS.
title: Genomic dissection of 43 serum urate-associated loci provides multiple insights into molecular mechanisms of urate control
